Award.AwardTitle: Belmont Forum-G8 Collaborative Research: Bangladesh Delta: Assessment of Sea-Level Rise Hazards and Integrated Predictive Development Towards Mitigation and Adaptation (BanD-AID)
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides support to U.S. researchers participating in a project competitively selected by a 13-country initiative on global change research through the Belmont Forum and the G8 countries Heads of Research Councils. The Belmont Forum is a high level group of the world's major and emerging funders of global environmental change research and international science councils. It aims to accelerate delivery of the international environmental research most urgently needed to remove critical barriers to sustainability by aligning and mobilizing international resources. The G8 Heads of Research Councils developed a funding framework to support multilateral research projects that address global challenges in ways that are beyond the capacity of national or bilateral activities. Each partner country provides funding for their researchers within a consortium to alleviate the need for funds to cross international borders. This approach facilitates effective leveraging of national resources to support excellent research on topics of global relevance best tackled through a multinational approach, recognizing that global challenges need global solutions.

Working together in an inaugural call of the International Opportunities Fund, the Belmont Forum and G8HORCs have provided support for research projects that seek to deliver knowledge needed for action to mitigate and adapt to detrimental environmental change and extreme hazardous events that relate to either Freshwater Security or Coastal Vulnerability. This award provides support for the U.S. researchers to cooperate in consortia that consist of partners from at least three of the participating countries and that bring together natural scientists, social scientists and research users (e.g., policy makers, regulators, NGOs, communities and industry).

This award supports research activities that will develop natural and social science frameworks to promote the adaptation to sea-level rise and related coastal hazards in coastal Bangladesh. Sea-level rise, changes in land-surface topography, and changes in the frequency of storms contribute to increasing vulnerability to coastal regions. This is especially true in Bangladesh, a low-lying coastal nation with a high population density that is also prone to hazards including monsoonal flooding, saltwater intrusion, erosion, and drinking water hazards. This project will quantify the causes of sea-level rise and land movement as well as the human interactions that govern coastal vulnerability in Bangladesh. An earth system analysis and prediction system will be constructed to promote the adaptation to and mitigation of these detrimental hazards. Using a range of satellite and ground instrumentation as well as socio-economic tools, this project will integrate improved sea-level rise predictions with land subsidence. This project will contribute an analysis and prediction framework to improve the coastal resilience of Bangladesh. The integrated development of a natural and social science framework will provide a novel decision support tool for the adaptation of sea-level rise that is transportable to other coastal regions of the world.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our Belmont coastal vulnerability project (BanD-AID), http://Belmont-BanDAid.org, has built a prototype of the Belmont Challenge identified Earth System Analysis & Prediction System (ESAPS) for the Bangladesh Delta. Our work addresses the Coastal Vulnerability Theme in the Belmont/G8 program by using an integrated human-natural science framework to study human adaptation to climate-induced hazards resulting from accelerated sea-level rise in coastal Bangladesh.  We use a novel approach to jointly characterize the natural processes, human interactions, and complex feedback effects that govern coastal vulnerability and resilience in Bangladesh. We studied sea-level rise in coastal Bangladesh using contemporary space geodetic and remote sensing data, and investigated the impact of environmental factors on various social and economic processes, including land use change, population increase, migration, and assessed the most important factors governing the vulnerability of the coastal systems. Our cross-disciplinary approach integrates social and natural sciences towards understanding adaptation and the alleviation of environmental vulnerability, with the ultimate goal of increasing local resilience in coastal Bangladesh.

We have built a prototype of an advanced observation system based on satellite remote sensing and geodetic measurements (gravimetry, altimetry, GPS and tide gauges), and social and natural science fieldworks to quantify: (1) the contributors of sea-level rise, and land motion at decadal or longer timescale and at fine spatial scales, (2) the human-nature interactions that govern coastal vulnerability and resilience in Bangladesh. Additional accomplishment of the project include: (1) the scientific quantification of sea-level rise and accounting for land subsidence over the last six decades using a novel finger-print approach, an estimate of sea level estimates and vertical land motion using a novel joint sea-level reconstruction and land motion adjustment method, the horizontal Bangladesh shoreline changes over the last 4 decades using Landsat imagery, and the use of two climate scenarios to project the Bangladesh Delta relative sea-level rise to the year 2100 and 2200;  and (2) the development of an integrated natural and social science framework involving flood/sea-level rise hazard adaptation via population migration, conversion of agricultural land to aquaculture and brackish ponds, with dedicated social science surveys, towards building a robust decision support service for mitigation and resilience to the effects of climate change in coastal Bangladesh.  The developed BanD-AID ESAPS prototype observing system is transportable to other regions of the world. Our work has leveraged and benefited other existing projects (e.g., Fulbright, NASA, NSF, ONR, USAID, World Bank). The project has trained students, technicians and academicians including NGOs, social workers, University, and government staffs within Bangladesh who will be the next-generation local stakeholders to address coastal vulnerability and resilience.
